Apart from her looks, the audience has also shown a liking towards her films.
News.Heading: Washing dirty linen in public is not right: Anjana
News.text: Does the name Anjana Sukhani ring a bell? Yes, she's the girl who had Anil Kapoor drooling as she danced to Babuji dheere chalna in 'Salaam-E-Ishq'. Almost nine years after that film, Anjana is experimenting with another ishq, this time a risky and passionate one. The actress is making her Marathi film debut opposite Swwapnil Joshi in the upcoming Laal Ishq. In a chat with us, Anjana shares how she landed the role, her non-filmi roots and personal space. Excerpts: After Tamil, Telugu, Kannada and Punjabi films, 'Laal Ishq' marks your Marathi debut. Tell us how things fell in place. Frankly, it was a cakewalk for me. I got a call from Sanjay Leela Bhansali's office (he's producing the film) and was asked to come down for an interaction. I met the director Swapna Waghmare-Joshi there, the team told me the story of the film and asked if I would like a narration. I said yes and the next thing I know, I was on board. Also read: Anjana is Bhansali's new heroine What is your character Janhavi like, in the film? It is not even close to my real self. Janhavi is honest but has shades of grey. It is a layered character and unlike anything I have done before. Playing Janhavi was emotionally draining for me. Firstly, I understand Marathi but speaking it in front of hundreds of people is not something I was comfortable with. So, getting the pronunciations, emotions and body-language right in a single scene was a task but credit goes to Swwapnil and Swapna tai for bringing out the best in me. Having said this, the role lifted me as an actor. Since you've worked in five different languages, according to you, where does regional cinema stand when compared to Bollywood? I won't really compare the two. Each film industry has its unique identity, stage, audience and practices. But I have grown personally and professionally whilst working in these industries; each film has been an enriching experience. For a love story, you have to have a certain rapport with your co-star. With this being your first pairing with Swwapnil and also your first Marathi outing, how did you ensure to get the scenes right? Swwapnil is a very humble human being. That made things easy and it didn't even take a week for us to break the ice. Plus, all of us were meeting daily and that ensured we got along soon. But was it difficult shooting the intimate scenes? No matter how much one denies it, there is always some hesitance when shooting an intimate scene. But an actor needs to shed inhibitions to look convincing. I follow a simple mantra - 'Do whatever it takes to get the shot right at the first go, instead of doing the same thing 40 times'. Was it difficult for you to make a mark in the film industry without a filmy background or any backing? I won't say it's difficult but you need to have determination to get where you want to. You are standing in a queue and you know there are thousands of girls standing behind you. Your number will come if you stay put but if you leave the queue, that's the end of it. Adhyayan Suman, your co-star from 'Jashn', is in the middle of the Hrithik-Kangana issue nowadays... All I want to say about this is that it's a very personal thing, what they are going through and washing dirty linen in public is wrong. Find out: Why Hrithik-Kangana's alleged affair got ugly Till date, you were recognised as Anjana from 'Salaam-E-Ishq'. Will things change post 'Laal Ishq'? I hope so. My brother watched the film and said 'this is a performance that'll take you where you want to be.' Do you follow Marathi films? Not very regularly, but since I had to work with Swwapnil, I watched all his films except 'Duniyadari'; that one is pending. I have watched 'Fandry', 'Double Seat' and 'Dr Prakash Baba Amte-The Real Hero' too. Is there any particular actor that you like? I feel that the Marathi industry has extremely talented actors. I am a big fan of Mukta Barve and recently had a fan-girl moment when I met her. I had been pestering Swwapnil to get a photo of mine with Mukta. That's off the checklist now. A lot of films suffered in the recent past due to the water-crisis in the state. Did you face a similar situation? Thankfully I haven't faced anything like this personally, but I am very much aware of the situation and sympathize with the farmers and people migrating to Mumbai from various parts of Maharashtra. I have immense respect for Nana Patekar in this regard, due to the work he is doing for the farmers. It has inspired me and I am also doing my bit towards helping those in need.
News.Heading: I came all the way from Hollywood looking for a job in India: Arnold
News.text: Hollywood superstar Arnold Schwarzenegger said that he was taken back to his younger days as a bodybuilder at the audio launch of Shankar's I. The glitzy audio launch, which also had Superstar Rajinikanth and Kannada actor Puneet Rajkumar as the special guests, had a special segment where bodybuilders who were part of the film, put on a show to a medley of filmi numbers. Arnold was moved by the show and individually congratulated every one of the bodybuilders. He went off script and took to the stage immediately, and said, "It feels like I'm back in my good old bodybuilding days. I thank director Shankar for giving these bodybuilders a job. But what about me? I came all the way from Hollywood looking for a job here. I want to act in your movies. Make a movie here with me, maybe Conan..." The actor also thanked the producer of I, Aascar Ravichandran, with who he said he has been associated for long. "He has been promoting my films in India in a huge way and I thank him for that," he remarked and signed off with his trademark dialogue, 'I'll be back'.
News.Heading: I dont waste time responding to every rumour: Mohanlal
News.text: Being one of the biggest movie stars in the country can often make one an easy target when it comes to controversies. But Mohanlal has always preferred to remain tight-lipped when it comes to them. When he did not put up a social media post on the demise of actor Kalabhavan Mani, it drew flak from some quarters, so did his recent blog post about the JNU issues. The actor seems unruffled by it all, and tells us why silence has always been the best policy for him. Prior to his family tour to South East Asia, we got the actor talking about his upcoming movie 'Pulimurugan', why he doesn't respond to every allegation about him, and his views on the Malayalam film industry. There's a lot of anticipation surrounding your next Malayalam film 'Pulimurugan'. What is its status now? We are almost done with the shooting and it will release in July. And yes, I have actually shot with a tiger for the movie. At first we had considered shooting with a leopard, but then found out that it runs too fast to be filmed. Getting a human to run with it is unrealistic. Tigers are more practical in that sense, as they are heavier. It weighs close to 300 kilos. A lot of graphics are involved but nearly 80 per cent of film was shot with a real tiger. How was the experience shooting with a tiger? I am not able to describe that in words. You have to actually be near a tiger to experience that feeling. But at the end of the day it's an animal. If everything goes well, the film will be the best action movie in our industry. It's got a universal subject and not many films have portrayed the relationship between man and animal. Apart from action, the film also has a lot of emotions involved and is a realistic story that everyone can relate to. I worked 115 days with the team and Peter Hein has choreographed the action scenes. We are trying to get it dubbed in Tamil, Telugu and Hindi. Plans are even in place to release a two-hour English version and also dub it in Chinese, Vietnamese and Spanish. Does it open up the possibility of Malayalam films too getting dubbed in other languages? We can't make every Malayalam film like that because of the costs involved. To dub a Malayalam movie into another language, for example Telugu, it has to have elements that would appeal to the audience there. People here watch Tamil and Telugu movies because they get to see a lot of gimmicks that they don't see in Malayalam. A hero in a Tamil film can blink and the next second he is in Switzerland. Industry-wise too Kerala is small. So what we can do is have an exchange of actors and fortunately that is increasingly happening these days. Many of our actors now work in Tamil and Telugu and vice versa. But we can't do it for every film. Your monthly blogs have drawn flak of late... Being an actor doesn't mean that I can't react to what's happening around me. I have been writing my blog for several years. Whenever I have written about pertinent subjects no one has supported them. For instance, the stray dog menace. I cycle in the morning every day and I am still scared of stray dog attacks. My concern is more about children who might not be able to fend off the attack than about myself. It's my right to write on what I feel about certain incidents and it's your choice, whether to read it or not. So is it a conscious decision to not respond to controversies? You feel hurt when you hear things which you are supposed to have said, which you wouldn't even have given a thought to. But if you start responding to such claims, it will only snowball into bigger debates. Most problems occur when you respond to something. But at times, you tend to respond as a reflex action. You should also see if the person you argue with is actually worth it. Now you have social media where it is easy for people to spin so many tales. The amount of time they waste on morphing images just to irritate or tarnish somebody's reputation is unbelievable! Recently I read the book When Breath Becomes Air, which talks about death and one's last moments. Our breath becomes air at a moment's notice and the instant before that is when we think about love, people, friends, God and how much time we have wasted. Time is important and people should use it positively. I believe so. That doesn't mean people can attack me with their words and actions. But you become seasoned and lose interest in responding, over time. A lot of people unnecessarily write things about me, file legal cases against me and make trolls on social media. This happens to all celebrities; I just consider it an occupational hazard. It's been 38 years in the industry and you must have made a lot of friends along the way. How easy has it been to maintain those friendships, given your stardom? Every day has something new to offer in our industry, especially because we keep shuttling between locations. At times you miss your friends and would be able to connect only when you meet. When I began my career, there were no mobile phones and we had limited ways of contacting each other. Now, it has become easier to connect with old friends. Ultimately, it's your decision whether you want to connect with your old friends or not. Some of my friendships are as long as 50 years. But that doesn't mean I have to call everyone I knew back then. A lot of people say that the bond we shared doesn't exist anymore because Mohanlal has become a big star now. I might remember that person but that doesn't mean I have to keep calling him every day, right? You are also part of several social awareness campaigns including one advocating organ donation. How involved are you in such projects? I believe that my purpose for being part of such programmes is served if at least one person benefits from it. I wrote about cleanliness recently in my blog and of late there has been a move to stop using plastic in railway stations and during events and functions. I have been talking about it in several meetings for the last five years. I keep repeating myself every year but it never translated into any action till recently.
News.Heading: Watch Sindhu Loknath sizzle
News.text: Kannada actress Sindhu Loknath is known for her girl-next-door image, but she seems to be working extra hard at getting rid of the tag. While her last film, Love in Manya, opposite Ninasam Sathish, had her portray a glimpse of her glam avataar in the song Currentu Hoda Timealli, her next film, Jai Bajarangabali, opposite Ajai Rao, has her attempting yet another glam avataar. The song, Hrudayada Battery, is sent against a futuristic backdrop and Sindhu, and Ajai are seen in the modern best. Watch the song Hrudayada Battery, from Jai Bajarangabali here.
News.Heading: Sai Tamhankar bags international project
News.text: Soon after making a mark in the Hindi film industry with Hunterrr, actress Sai Tamhankar is all set to appear in an international project titled 'Love Sonia'. She will be seen sharing screen space with big names like Anupam Kher, Frieda Pinto Adil Hussain, Manoj Bajpayee, Rajkummar Rao and Richa Chadha in the film, which revolves around the issue of sex-trafficking. Speculations about Sai's association with the project arose soon after a photo of her having dinner with some cast and crew members was uploaded online. Confirming the same to us, Sai said, "I feel blessed to be a part of this big project which has superlatively talented actors. I play the role of Anjali in the film. David Womark, who has produced and written the screenplay for the film, loved my performance in Hunterrr and that was taken into consideration while selecting me for this role." News.Heading: Mallika Sarabhai's multi-media dance-drama in Hyderabad

She knows what her work entails and what it means to be a teacher. She also works as a counsellor in a juvenile home in Kerala," says Vijay Menon. About the movie, the director says, "While it has a serious theme and a strong message about social responsibility, it will be an entertainer." The film is scripted by Vijay's son Nikhil. Talking about his experience working with his dad, the engineering student says that the initial plan was to write a book on the subject. "When I presented the story to my dad, he asked me to make a screenplay out of it. I put in a lot of work and I believe we have a solid script now," Nikhil says. Vijay though tells us that although he liked his son's work, he was not convinced about directing it himself. "I was a bit sceptical initially, thinking that I am just being biased because he is my son. So, I took it to Renji Panicker, who read it at a stretch in two hours and asked me to go ahead," he says. Apart from Bhavana, 'Vilakkumaram' also has actors Manoj K Jayan, Suraj Venjaramoodu and Vinod Kovoor. "A lot of kids will also be part of the film that will go on floors today," says Vijay, adding that film will be shot in Trivandrum and Ladakh.
News.Heading: Fake Friday the 13th terror attack on Cannes film stars' hotel
News.text: CANNES: A fake terror attack panicked guests at the French Riviera hideaway of several Hollywood stars at the Cannes film festival, police said. The publicity stunt, by a French internet company aimed at the super rich, saw a speedboat full of men in helmets and military style uniforms attempt to storm the dock of the five- star Hotel du Cap just around the bay from Cannes. Guests said the men were dressed as an "ISIS-like" militia group, referring to the Islamic State group which killed 130 people in a night of attacks on Paris six months ago. Their inflatable speedboat also flew a black flag similar to the one used by IS. Chillingly, the stunt happened on Friday, the first Friday the 13th since the bloodshed in Paris last November. American publicist J.R. Savet, who was dining on the terrace with Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter when the boat approached, said guests were shocked. "Someone screamed and people jumped out of their chairs and started moving quickly to the swimming pool area. It was pretty scary," he told the Hollywood Reporter. Cannes has been on high terror alert for the 12-day film festival, with a warship moored in the bay and snipers posted on hotel roofs. Oraxy, the Paris-based internet company that organised the stunt, has not yet replied to AFP requests for comment. It describes itself on its website as "the world's first private global marketplace reserved... for Ultra High Net Worth Individuals." A police spokesman told that the men involved in the stunt had earlier tried to breach a sea exclusion zone around Cannes but had been repulsed by the authorities. He said that the men then tried to land at the hotel. Paramilitary gendarmes seized the boat, but the men were not formally arrested. "These men know that they have really overstepped the mark and today they feel ashamed," he added. A justice official told that those behind the stunt were "likely to pay very dearly," and would be prosecuted for breaking maritime rules and for inflicting "psychological trauma". The authorities were also investigating who owns the boat and rented it out, he said. The speedboat had earlier buzzed the yacht of Hollywood legend Steven Spielberg, the "Seven Seas", and another owned by Russian billionaire and Chelsea football club owner Roman Abramovich. The Hotel du Cap - also known as Eden Roch - on the ritzy Cap d'Antibes, refused to comment on the incident or say which stars were in the hotel at the time.
News.Heading: Dulquer Salmaan plays a Thrissurkkaran in Sathyan Anthikads film

News.Heading: Only after my grandfather passed away did I realise how much my life revolved around him: Rana
News.text: "My thatha's death was the biggest blow I've dealt with in all my life," says Rana Daggubati, recalling how he broke down inconsolably when 'Movie Mogul' Dr D Ramanaidu passed away earlier this year. "I have never seen death in my family, especially not of someone who's so close to me...I might be this big guy from the outside, but I'm very sensitive when it comes to my family," says Rana, who admits that he misses his grandfather more than ever as time goes by. "He would have turned 79 today had he been around," says Rana, his voice choking with emotion. "It was only after he passed on that I realised how much my life revolved around him. Whenever I pass by his car, room or office, which all lie empty now, I feel his absence. It's difficult to put it in words, you know... It's almost like there is so much left to say, but you just don't get a second chance..." And yet, Ramanaidu lives on in the collective memories of the Daggubati family, avers Rana. "We tend to talk about him a lot more these days... He is part of almost every conversation we have at home. After all, he was the pillar of the entire family; his demise has left a huge void which cannot be filled." Life was in the little details for Ramanaidu, and the family still strives to keep intact the little traditions he started. "For instance, he always insisted that the entire family eats together, as long as we were in town. So, two of the three meals were a family affair. We still keep that practice intact," Rana says. Life lessons Ramanaidu gave him is the other thing that Rana holds close to his heart. "He taught me the value of discipline and punctuality... he was a living example of that. He was a methodical man and he stuck to the same schedule with clockwork precision all his life. He'd leave home at 9 am, return for lunch at 1 pm, rest for a couple of hours, and step out again at 4 pm. His day would end a little after 8 pm, post dinner. we were all in perfect sync with his timing. And we all imbibed this discipline into our own lives." As it goes often with life and death, what's left behind are a handful of memories, and Rana says it's the fond memories of time spent with his grandfather as a child that he treasures the most. "I remember spending a lot of time with thatha in my native village, Karamchedu. when we first moved to Hyderabad, I remember him taking me on long drives in his new car every time there was a power cut at home. This was in the early 90s, when the Jubilee Hills area was still a sparsely populated, hilly terrain... I'll cherish those memories forever." So, like most grandparents do, did Ramanaidu also wish to see his grandson married? "Oh... not really," Rana says, adding, "He never liked to impose his thoughts on others. Thatha lived his life to the fullest and he wanted us to do the same. Now you know where that side of mine comes from," he quips, with a smile.
News.Heading: Yoga and walking helped me to shed my weight: Raashi Khanna
News.text: After working out for almost one year, actress Raashi Khanna has finally shed the chubby look and is "six kilos lighter"! What the actress is most surprised to discover was that, yoga and meditation turned out to be more effective in her case, than hitting the gym. "I used to work out twice a day; but to no avail. I kept adding muscle, without losing fat despite following a diet of fish and eggs. It all changed when I went to a spa resort near Haridwar earlier this year. I began to meditate, practice yoga and walk a lot every day. And all that helped me detox." Her exercise regimen is a combination of yoga, dance, walking and two days of functional training at the gym, every week. The trick she lies in figuring out your body type, she says. "I lost six kilos in the past few months, but more than that, I finally figured out what form of exercise works best for my body. It feels great, you know. I've been training in contemporary bollywood dance and working on all the thumkas. I keep pushing the bar and I'm surprised I can pull off some good moves. It's also a good cardio exercise," she says, laughing. Of late, Raashi has been juggling between the sets of Ravi Teja's Bengal Tiger and Ram-starrer Shivam. "Ram is extremely talented and he's full of surprises. Moreover, he has helped me a lot to get my expressions right while acting in a scene. On the other hand, Ravi Teja is a bundle of energy and he's extremely fit. There's always a positive vibe on the sets when he's around," she says signing off.
News.Heading: Whatever I am today is because of tV: Siddharth Shukla
News.text: Actor Siddharth Shukla, who will be making his filmy debut soon, credits his success to TV shows. I WILL NEVER LEAVE TV Actor Siddharth Shukla is absolutely certain that he will not leave television. After signing a three film deal with producer director Karan Johar, Siddharth is making his Bollywood debut with Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania. While in Lucknow to promote the show Balika Vadhu, in which he plays Shivraj Anoop Shekhar, Anandi's husband, Siddharth says that he will try and work out a balance between TV and films. "Whatever I am today is because of television, so I will never leave TV completely. As it is, films are a new experience for me where as TV is a known medium. A lot of credit for my success today goes to the serial Balika Vadhu," says the tall good looking actor. ALSO READ: Siddharth Shukla gets nostalgic 'Jhalak...' set BALIKA IS NOT AT THE END OF ITS ROAD Defending his show Siddhartha says that viewers are still loving his show. "See, everyone at some point of time feels a little lazy and drained out. Similarly for a TV show too. Kabhi achha lagta hai, kabhi nahi. This see-saw thing goes on everywhere but that doesn't mean you put an end to it. In fact later, you will work doubly hard to make up for that complacency. Same is the case with our show. We are constantly coming up with new tracks to keep the viewers attracted to the show. And it's simple, had the show not been doing well, the channel wouldn't have kept giving us extensions. It's been running strong for the past six years. There's a lot more left to do in Balika...," says he. TV IS NOT A FEMALE DOMINATED MEDIUM Siddharth doesn't feel that content on TV is women oriented. "Nothing can work without a balance. I agree Balika... initially focused mainly on Anandi, but over the years, even the men are getting their due. In fact I feel that goes for all shows on TV. There are no leads in a serial. Mainly because a story can't function with just one person. At some point or the other, every character gets prominence over the others and they become the lead in the show at that time. For instance in Balika..., the focus is on my character Shiv these days, so in that sense I am the lead," says Siddharth with a smile. READ: No girl would want to be in relationship with me says Siddharth Shukla NO TIME FOR LOVE Touted as one of the most eligible bachelors of the small screen, Siddharth takes the compliment with a question , "Really? Where are the girls?, adding, "I like the company of women but given my present situation I am sure no girl would like to date me. I have such a busy schedule from 5 am to 11 pm, that I can't devote time to anyone however much I may like to. For the time being I have to remain single," says he with a shrug. News.Heading: Havent kissed my co-star: Rani Chatterjee

News.Heading: Kunchackos Kochuouvva is based on a real person
News.text: Real-life characters are increasingly serving as fodder for Malayalam movies of late. After Nivin Pauly's 'Jacobinte Swargarajyam', Kunchacko Boban's upcoming movie Kochuouvva Paulo Ayyappa Coelho has also borrowed elements from the life of a real person. In tune with its title, the film revolves around two characters Kochuouvva played by Kunchacko Boban and Ayyappa Das portrayed by actor Sudheesh's son Master Rudraksh. The former plays a character who tries to fix others' problems. "My character Kochuouvva is based on a real person," says Kunchacko Boban. "If we actually mirror his real-life actions and generosity on screen, the audience would find it too cinematic. The irony is that we actually had to tone down his actions a bit for the film." While the actor doesn't reveal who the character is based on, he says that the movie has a fresh theme that would appeal to everyone. "The central characters in the movie have different aims in life but a particular incident unites their path towards these goals. Paulo Coelho's writings are what bring them together," explains the 'School Bus' actor. Incidentally, the film will once again have Kunchacko playing a rustic youth similar to the character in his latest release directed by Rishi Sivakumar. "While it has a serious theme at the core, director Sidhartha Siva has ensured that the film is made in a very entertaining way. It will be a refreshing movie, replete with songs and a lot of humour." 'Kochuouvva Paulo Ayyappa Coelho', which also has Aju Varghese and Suraj Venjaramoodu, has already finished two schedules and is currently waiting for the monsoons to hit to resume the shooting. However, the team is yet to zero in on the lead actress for the movie.

News.Heading: My mom taught me to be independent: Aparna Gopinath
News.text: Aparna Gopinath is a self-confessed mommy's girl. The actress, who has always stood apart from the rest , off and on screen, says that it is her mother who has influenced her the most in life, be it in her life or career. "My mother has influenced me the most in my life. She was the one who taught me to have courage and strength, to be a confident individual and not get carried away by all that glitters," she says. ""She taught me to always stand on my own two feet and to be independent." Her mother is also the reason she is an actress today, Aparna adds. "She gifted me with the greatest present in my life by introducing me to the stage. I am who I am today, as a person and as a professional, because of my mom." However, despite all this, her mother still treats her like a baby, she admits. "She spoils me silly and gives in to all of my whims and fancies. She treats me like I am five years old even today and I wouldn't have it any other way."

News.Heading: Govind Padmasoorya to flaunt his Zumba moves
News.text: Govind Padmasoorya might have relinquished his dance show host duties but that's not stopping him from shaking a leg. The actor is all set to showcase his moves as a Zumba instructor in the upcoming Ranjith Sankar directorial, 'Pretham'. "I play Shibu Majeed, who is a globetrotter," says Padmasoorya. "He is an engineering graduate, who was forced to do an MBA in the US by his parents. Once there, he found that the business degree was not his cup of tea, so he dropped out and opted for philosophy, which he again gave up. Meanwhile, he enrolled for Zumba classes in his free time and realised that was his true calling. So, he trains to become a Zumba instructor, much to the ire of his family." Did his dance skills have anything to do with him landing the role? "There isn't too much dance involved but it would help me to get into the shoes of the character. Also, he is a happy-go-lucky, flirtatious guy, which I could relate to, I guess." The horror-comedy, which will go on floors within a fortnight, also has Jayasurya, Aju Varghese and Joju George. "The movie is different from Ranjith's previous films like 'Punyalan Agarbatties' and 'Su.. Su.. Sudhi Vathmeekam', which were motivational movies. While 'Pretham' is an entertainer, it will be experimental in terms of the filmmaking style and its theme will delve into something that's not often discussed," explains Padmasoorya.
News.Heading: SikhNet To Launch Free Online Animated Story 'Kaur'
News.text: SikhNet To Launch Free Online Animated Story for International Women's Day - in celebration of International Women's Day, SikhNet will launch an original short animated film, titled KAUR, free online. #makeithappen. #kaurpower. kaur.sikhnet.com. KAUR tells the story of a young Sikh girl, Saibhang Kaur, who loves science but feels the social pressure that "girls don't belong in science club." Not sure what to do about her dreams, Saibhang Kaur thinks about giving up. But when Saibhang's grandmother tells her the true story of the 18th century Sikh warrior princess Mai Bhago, Saibhang discovers her courage. The idea for KAUR began four years ago when SikhNet webmaster, Gurumustuk Singh Khalsa, wrote a blog article bemoaning how his daughter loved to imitate Disney princesses. He posed the question - wouldn't it be great for there to be an animated story about true-life, powerful 'princess' figures that his daughter could imitate, instead? Upon reading the blog post, an anonymous donor made a sizeable contribution to SikhNet, creating seed money for the project. SikhNet has produced over 100 original audio stories for kids. However, they had never produced an original animation before, so it took time for the company to decide what to do with the money. Four years later - the result is KAUR. KAUR focuses on two stories simultaneously. The story of a young girl who has to deal with the modern version of "women belong in the kitchen," and the story of Mai Bhago, an amazing Sikh woman warrior who led 40 men into battle against an army over 10,000 strong. This small band of Sikhs defended the principles of freedom and equality against a medieval version of ISIS. In KAUR, the story of Mai Bhago helps Saibhang Kaur find the strength to face the battles in her own life. SikhNet has chosen to launch the animation in celebration of International Women's Day. The struggles of Saibhang Kaur represent the struggles of so many young women around the world seeking to find a place for themselves beyond traditional roles. Mai Bhago is a true-life heroine, whose story can inspire all girls, everywhere. The animation will be available FREE online beginning on March 3rd at: kaur.sikhnet.com. It has a running time of approximately 20 minutes. News.Heading: OMG: Vishal attacked at Nadigar Sangam elections
News.text: Nadigar Sangam elections took yet another ugly turn on Sunday. We hear that actor Vishal was attacked at the venue and that he is reportedly injured. It is said that actress Sangeetha was manhandled by a mob at the election venue and when actor Vishal tried to intervene, he was attached and was injured in his right hand. The actor, we hear, is being given a special treatment inside the caravan. The police then immediately turned up at the venue and the voting is on in full swing. It was earlier said that when actor Mohan had reached the venue, someone had already cast a proxy vote for him.
News.Heading: Shruti Haasan plays a taxi driver in Thala 56
News.text: Rumours were rife that Ajith was to play a taxi driver in his next film directed by Siruthai Siva. However, we now hear that it is the leading lady of the film Shruti Haasan, who plays the role of a taxi driver and not Ajith. The actress has recently joined the set and now, the team has wrapped up the first schedule. A source from the unit says, "Shruti Haasan is kicked about her role. She plays a taxi driver, who drives in Kolkata. She is donning a khaki uniform too. She has recently shot in Chennai and the crew may travel to Kolkata for the next schedule of the film. So, it is Shruti who's playing the driver, not Ajith." Sources also say that a huge set that resembles certain places in Kolkata has been erected in Chennai. Apart from that, the team may head to Kolkata to shoot some of the scenes. During the month-long schedule, which concluded recently, Siva canned portions of Ajith and Lakshmi Menon. Shruti shot for just couple of days during this schedule and she will shoot for major portions of the film in the next schedule only.
News.Heading: Khesari Lal Yadavs next goes on floors
News.text: Under the banner of Shivbaksh Production, Rajasthan based producer Abhimanyu Mittal's upcoming film, which is yet untitled, recently went on floors. It is directed by well-known filmmaker Manjul Thakur, who last film Raja Babu went on to be a success at the box office. The film stars Khesari Lal Yadav in the lead along with Anjana Singh, Kajal Raghwani, Sanjay Pande, Manoj Tiger, Vinod Mishra and others. A large majority of its shoot has already been completed in Khalilabad, Gorakhpur. The remaining portions would be shot in Mumbai and Rajasthan. Mittal has revealed that he has two more films in the pipeline after this one. The pre-production of both films has already begun.
News.Heading: Singer Karthik performs with his band Arka at a party at ITC Grand Chola, Chennai
News.text: It was an evening of music, laughter, camaraderie and good food at a recent event in a star hotel in the city. The evening started off with singer Karthik, performing with his band Arka, comprising musicians like Selvaganesh, Ravichandra Kulur, Gino Banks, Myshko and Santosh. The band indulged the audience with some lilting numbers, which were a fusion of Indian and Western music. Present at the do were a mix from social circles, the film and music industries. Singers Haricharan and Naresh Iyer were spotted enjoying the music by the band. Also spotted were Rajiv Menon and Latha, Mandolin Rajesh, Lakshmi and Saraswathi and Bharat Joshi with his wife, among others. All in all, it was an evening to remember.
News.Heading: Pig's head found outside Angela Merkel's constituency office
News.text: BERLIN: German police said on Saturday they found a pig's head bearing an "insulting inscription" outside Chancellor Angela Merkel's constituency office in the country's northeast. A police patrol discovered the animal's head outside the office in the Baltic sea town of Stralsund in the early hours of Saturday. A spokesman for regional police refused to be drawn on the nature of the insults, saying only that they were directed at Merkel, who was first elected to parliament in Stralsund 26 years ago. The conservative chancellor has been criticised by many Germans over her welcoming stance towards the migrants that have poured into Europe over the past year. The anti-immigration Alternative for Germany (AfD) has been buoyed by concerns over the integration of the more than one million asylum-seekers that arrived in Germany in 2015, becoming the country's third-biggest party. Merkel's migrant policies have also been contested by some members of her own Christian Democratic Union (CDU) as well as its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU).
News.Heading: Mexico unhappy with Egypt's response on 2015 attack on tourists
News.text: MEXICO CITY: Mexico released a statement on Thursday stating that it was not satisfied with the Egyptian government's response to an aerial bombing in Egypt last year in which eight Mexican tourists were killed. The Foreign Ministry published the statement on its website in which it said that it had sent a letter to the Egyptian embassy to express its "surprise and dissatisfaction" with the government's failure to thoroughly investigate the case, penalize the perpetrators and compensate victims. In addition to the eight Mexicans, four Egyptians were also killed while six other Mexicans were wounded. Last September, an Egyptian army aircraft fired on a group parked for a barbecue near a tourist site, presuming them to be militants. The ministry said that although media outlets had reported on negotiations with one of the victim's families, Mexico did not have any knowledge of the case. The New York Times reported earlier this week that the Egyptian tourism federation would compensate families of three Mexican victims and it was also negotiating with families of the other Mexican victims.
News.Heading: Lightning in Bangladesh kills 42
News.text: DHAKA: At least 42 people, including women and children, were killed in Bangladesh within the last 24 hours after being struck by lightning during thundershowers, officials said on Friday. Meteorological office said the downpour brought with it thundershowers in 14 districts, including Dhaka. Nine people were killed in five districts on Friday as rain has been lashing several parts of the country after a spell of heat waves. Thirty-three people, including children and women, were killed on Thursday in 12 different districts. The lightning that accompanied the seasonal nor'wester storms claimed the highest eight lives in northwestern Pabna, five each in neighbouring Sirajganj and Rajshahi districts. Police said Dhaka, Chittagong, Joypurhat and Naogaon saw two deaths each while one person died after being struck by bolt in Sunamganj on Friday. In Dhaka, sudden thunderbolts killed two engineering students when they were playing football in the rain. Four persons died in Kishoreganj and Brahmanbarhia each, reports said. Eleven more deaths were reported from other parts of the country. The casualties included a number of children who were playing in open grounds during the rain but mostly the victims were farmers, including women, who were in their fields. Rains appeared as a welcome shower after a heat wave scorched the country, but the downpour brought with it the lightning that caused the unusually high number of casualties. "Bangladesh witnesses the seasonal nor'wester storm every year from March to May when the thunderbolts also occur," meteorologist Hafizur Rahman said adding that the phenomenon appears mostly in northwestern Rajsahi and Sylhet regions. Fellow meteorologist Sujit Kumar Deb Sharma said lightning kills up to 300 people on an average each year in Bangladesh though not all the incidents were not reported in the media. The Met office has predicted rain or thundershowers with gusty or squally wind today in Dhaka, and in northwestern and northeastern regions. Some areas in southwestern and northwestern parts of the country may also receive rain and thundershowers.
News.Heading: China raising troop strength on border with India, Pentagon says
News.text: WASHINGTON: China is deploying more troops on the border with India while modernizing its nuclear force and improving its strike capabilities, the Pentagon has said, even as the Obama administration challenged Beijing's assertion that New Delhi does not meet the criteria to be a member of the Nuclear Suppliers Group. The state department, referring to Obama's statement in 2015, said India "meets missile technology control regime requirements and is ready for NSG membership". The shadow play between Washington, Beijing, and New Delhi was very much in evidence on Friday as the US defence establishment highlighted China's growing military strength in the region, ostensibly with an eye on courting India as a strategic counterweight. "We have noticed an increase in capability and force posture by the Chinese military in areas close to the border with India ," US deputy assistant secretary of defence for East Asia Abraham Denmark said during a news conference after Pentagon submitted its annual 2016 report to the US Congress on 'Military and Security Developments Involving the People's Republic of China'. "It's difficult to say how much of this is driven by internal considerations to maintain internal stability, and how much of it is an external consideration." But as far as Washington is concerned, he added, it would continue to enhance bilateral engagement with India "not in the China context but because India is an increasingly important player" by itself. "We are going to engage India because of its value," Denmark said. Beijing increasing military presence A series of reports and remarks from Washington amid continuing tensions with China is coming just ahead of PM Narendra Modi's visit alongside India's own issues with Beijing, notably its use of Pakistan to needle India on issues such as terrorism and access to advanced nuclear technology. But in a report to the US Congress, the Pentagon warned of China's increasing military presence including bases in various parts of the world, in particular Pakistan with which it has a "longstanding friendly relationship and similar strategic interests". China's expanding international economic interests are increasing demands for the PLA Navy (PLAN) to operate in more distant seas to protect Chinese citizens, investments, and critical sea lines of communication, it said, adding, "China most likely will seek to establish additional naval logistics hubs in countries with which it has a longstanding friendly relationship and similar strategic interests, such as Pakistan, and a precedent for hosting foreign militaries." READ ALSO: Indian, Chinese armies resolve to maintain peace in border meet The US navy itself is now working even more closely with the Indian Navy , outlining the emerging contours of efforts to dominate the sea lanes in the Indian Ocean through which some 60% of the world's energy trade passes. Meanwhile, Washington also endorsed India's claim for a membership of the Nuclear Suppliers Group that the China-Pakistan axis has been thwarting . "I'd point you back to what the President said during his visit to India in 2015, where he reaffirmed that the US view was that India meets missile technology control regime requirements and is ready for NSG membership," State Department spokesman John Kirby said when asked about reports about Beijing and Islamabad joining hands to stall India's NSG membership. China has claimed that many members of the 48-nation NSG share its view that signing of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) is an "important" standard for the group's expansion, an assertion that Washington does not agree with. The western world's support for India's membership is based in part on its sterling non-proliferation record, which Pakistan, as a rogue proliferator, and China as an illegal enabler, cannot match. All these issues are being thrashed out in private ahead of PM Modi's visit to Washington on June 7-8 in what promises to be one of the most consequential visits by an Indian leader to the US.
News.Heading: Belgium to air strike Syria, against IS: PM spokesman
News.text: BRUSSELS: Belgium will extend its F-16 airstrikes against Islamic State jihadists in Iraq into Syria, the government said Friday, as it grapples with the fallout from deadly IS-claimed bomb attacks in Brussels in March. "In accordance with UN Resolution 2249, the engagement will be limited to those areas of Syria under the control of IS and other terrorist groups," a spokesman for Prime Minister Charles Michel told AFP after a cabinet meeting. More updates on the same are awaited.
News.Heading: Escaped US inmate found hiding in dishwasher of his girlfriends apartment
News.text: A Texas county jail inmate who escaped custody while receiving treatment in a hospital was found in the dishwasher of his girlfriend's apartment in boxer shorts and wearing handcuffs with the chain severed, a sheriff's department said on Thursday. "He took out the racks and made himself a nice cubby hole," said chief deputy Glenn Blank of the Jasper county sheriff's office in East Texas. The inmate, Wesley Evans, 20, was captured on Wednesday morning and was taken back into custody after an escape that lasted about 24 hours. He is expected to face charges for the escape attempt. Evans has been in jail since March 8 on charges of aggravated robbery, auto theft and arson. He was taken to the hospital for treatment of a swollen hand.
News.Heading: Buddhist monk hacked to death in Bangladesh: Police
News.text: DHAKA: A 75-year-old Buddhist monk was found hacked to death Saturday in Bangladesh's remote southeastern district of Bandarban, police said, the latest in a spate of murders of religious minorities and secular activists. The body of Maung Shue U. Chak was found Saturday morning by his daughter-in-law when she went to give him some food, local police official Abul Khayer said. His throat had been slit overnight. While no one immediately claimed responsibility for the killing, it follows a slew of murders in recent years of members of religious minority groups, foreigners, atheist bloggers and secular publishers in Bangladesh by suspected Islamist radicals. The killings have come amid growing concern that religious extremism is gaining ground in the Muslim-majority nation of 160 million. The Islamic State group and an al-Qaida-linked group have claimed responsibility for some of the recent killings. But the authorities in Bangladesh insist that neither of the groups has a presence in the country. Instead, the authorities have blamed political opposition and local militant groups for the violence. Last month, suspected Islamist militants killed two prominent gay rights activists, an atheist student and a university professor. Read this story in Marathi
News.Heading: Relations with Pakistan are important, says the US
News.text: WASHINGTON: The US is committed to maintaining its "important" and "vital" relationship with Pakistan, the Obama Administration said amid reports of strains in bilateral ties. "It is an important, vital relationship that we strongly believe in. Is it complicated at times? Absolutely it is. And do we see eye-to-eye on every issue with Pakistan? No, we don't," state department spokesman, John Kirby told reporters at his daily news conference. "But that's why the relationship matters so much because we have shared threats and shared concerns, shared interests in the region. And we're going to continue to work at it," he said. Kirby was responding to a question on the statement made by Prime Minister's adviser on foreign affairs Sartaj Aziz that his country's relationship with the United States has been under stress for the past three months. Kirby said he has not seen the statement. "I didn't see his comments. So I'm going to refrain from responding specifically to that sentiment," he said. Kirby did not agree when asked if the US-Pakistan ties are not at the best of times these days. "It is an important relationship that we continue to work at very, very seriously. We're going to remain committed to. And I would not share that characterization of it," Kirby said.
News.Heading: Three US teens live-stream sex acts on Facebook
News.text: NEW YORK: Police are looking for three teens in the US who skipped school to live-stream themselves engaging in sex acts on Facebook to their classmates, a media report said. On January 14, 2016, four juvenile students viewed a livestream on the social media website using their cell phones during health class at 1 p.m. The students said the videos show a 14-year-old girl, a 15-year-old girl and 15-year-old boy engaging in sex acts, the report added. Police in Milwaukee city of the US are asking Facebook to hand over all the information it has on the account of a 14-year-old girl. From pictures, status history and videos to user information like name, email, and IP address, a report on CBS58.com said. Meanwhile, Milwaukee Public Schools released a statement saying in January, staff became aware of a video depicting inappropriate conduct that took place outside of school and off campus. "The school immediately notified proper authorities and cooperated with the investigation. We took appropriate disciplinary action against those involved, which would be in addition to any outside consequences they may face," the statement said. A Milwaukee County search warrant notes that the two juvenile girls in the video could be charged with "exposing a child to harmful material" while the 15-year-old boy that participated in the sexual acts was not listed as a suspect on the warrant. The video was viewed by students at Barack Obama School but was not filmed there. The two girls in the videos attend the school but according to the school principal, the two suspects skipped school after the first period, the report said.
News.Heading: India-US Brain trust to deepen scientific collaboration
News.text: WASHINGTON: India and the US have formed a Brain Trust aimed at deepening and strengthening cooperation between the best and brightest in the scientific community of the world's two largest democracies. The partnership between the Indian and American scientific community, researchers, academicians, businesses and entrepreneurs is a "win-win" for not only the two countries, but also the entire world, said Indian ambassador to the US Arun K Singh. "We find now a strategic convergence in our interest and we are working together in different areas," he said in his address at the inaugural dinner of the Indo-US Brain Trust here on Thursday. A partnership for research and development and scientific collaboration is essential to take this relationship to the next level, he said. "There is a huge potential there," he added. "Several major US companies have developed products in India, which their CEOs have said to me they could not have developed in the US because researchers and scientists here approach the problem from different perspective with different resource availability, they are targeting with different objective," Singh said. "Whereas in India the aim very often is to minimize the use of resources, keep the cost down, maximize the number of people that can be reached through the product and thereby you end up with something that is different and has relevance in a different context," he said. Applauding India's success, former World Bank president Paul Wolfowitz said India has now emerged as a model for other developing countries. "The idea is to create a platform- which partners scientific minds from both countries to explore and create timely solutions to pressing global challenges," said Ron Somers founder and CEO of India First Group welcoming the guests at the inaugural dinner. "The Indo-US Brain Trust must strive to create a shared platform for the US and Indian scientific communities to exchange, synergize, and deepen collaboration," he added. Dr Krishna K Banaudha, an Indian-American scientist and the brain behind the project, said Indo-US Brain Trust intends to assemble some of the finest minds and friends who, by their very actions and livelihoods, support a deepening of US-India collaboration in science, research, academia, entrepreneurship and innovation. "This group collectively represents the extraordinary partnership underway between the United States and India which is shaping a very bright future," he said.
News.Heading: Double-amputee Ecuadoran mountaineer looks to climb K2 with artificial limbs
News.text: ILALO, ECUADOR: An Ecuadoran who lost both his feet is aiming to become the first climber to scale the world's toughest mountain, K2, with artificial limbs and without oxygen supplies. Santiago Quintero had half of each foot amputated for frostbite after climbing Aconcagua in Argentina in 2002. But that has not stopped him. "They told me I would never climb 5,000-meter mountains again," the smiling 41-year-old told AFP. "But no one can tell me how I am and what I am. Being what I want to be is my decision." Quintero scaled Mount Everest, the world's highest peak at 8,848 meters (29,029 feet), in 2013. The expedition landed him in the hospital in intensive care. Now he is aiming to conquer K2 -- the second-highest mountain at 8,611 meters, but considered technically the hardest to climb. He ascended K2, which is on the border between China and Pakistan, once before but stopped short of the summit. His party had to turn back when they sank up to their chests in snow. He says he caught frostbite on Aconcagua, the highest peak in the Americas, because he could not afford a $100 pair of waterproof covers for his boots. He spent nine months in the hospital in Spain, where doctors performed the amputations, then a further five years waiting to have prosthetic feet fitted. With those artificial members, he has already scaled seven of the 14 mountains in the world that are over 8,000 meters high. In total 188 mountaineers have scaled K2. "They did it with their bodies fully intact," said Quintero. "That's quite different." He plans to start his hike up K2 on June 13 and finish on July 31. "I am quite determined," he told AFP, while resting during a training climb on the extinct Ilalo volcano in northern Ecuador. "Without the mountains, I think I would rather be dead."
News.Heading: Sadiq Khan's temple visit pictures a hit online
News.text: He has shot to fame as London's first 'Muslim' mayor. And the Swaminarayan Temple in Neasden, a Hindu shrine, is among Saqid Khans's favourite places in the city. In a recent Facebook post, Khan has expressed his fondness for the temple. Pictures of Khan visiting the temple days before being elected as the mayor have gone viral where Khan is seen interacting with people from other faiths at the temple. He even holds out his hand for a priest to tie a string around his wrist, in keeping with a Hindu custom. Khan has declared his intentions to stand up for the London's Indian community and further strengthen the city's friendship with India. He called himself the 'most pro-business' London mayor ever, and expressed interest in leading a trade delegation to India. He also vowed to challenge the present government's 'unfair visa restrictions' that often make it difficult for businesses to find the best skilled employees.
News.Heading: 53 killed in natural disasters in China in April
News.text: BEIJING: As many as 53 people were killed and 16 others listed missing in natural disasters across China last month which affected more than 5.6 million people and caused direct economic losses of about $550 million. The disasters included drought, earthquakes, floods, forest fires, gales and hail, state-run Xinhua news agency reported on Saturday, citing a Ministry of Civil Affairs statement released on Friday. They caused about 3.6 billion yuan (about $550 million) in direct economic losses, it said. More than 53,000 people had to be relocated, 28,000 of whom needed emergency assistance, while about 6,000 houses collapsed, mostly in southern regions hit by floods, the report said. Overall damage was generally less than in the same period last year, during which 68 people were killed.
News.Heading: Ranchi: CRPF officer sent to jail, husband held
News.text: RANCHI: The Central Bureau of Investigation on Friday produced the CRPF deputy commandant Vinita Kumari in the court of a special CBI judge which forwarded her to jail on 14 days judicial custody. The CBI has registered a case against Kumari, deputy commandant with CRPF (133 Bn) Ranchi, who was arrested on Thursday, and unknown others for alleged illegal involvement in the recruitment process in CRPF. Meanwhile, her husband Dr Arvind Kumar Singh, also accused of helping her wife in irregularities in recruitment, was called for interrogation and was arrested on Friday. A press release from the CBI office said: "It was alleged in the complaint that the officer had approached medical officers of the recruitment board to declare medically unfit candidates as fit in lieu of illegal gratification. It was further alleged that the officer has also requested the medical officers of the medical board to intimate bank particulars by opening a new bank account, so that the alleged bribe can be deposited in the new bank accounts."
News.Heading: MP, nine MLAs detained with 9000 during Jharkhand bandh
News.text: RANCHI: With over 9000 supporters, JMM's Rajmahal MP Vijay Hansda and nine MLAs (all from different locations in Jharkhand) were detained on Saturday when they were trying to enforce a day-long bandh to mark a protest against the recently implemented local resident policy in the state. The state government implemented local resident policy in April which says anyone living in Jharkhand (besides some other provisions) since 1985 is a local. The JMM-led protesters claim the policy is tilted towards non-Tribals and want the cut-off date to be 1932. Two vehicles were torched in Jamshedpur and Bokaro (one in each). Suspected bandh supporters torched a truck and a bus in Jamshedpur. A passenger auto was vandalized in Ranchi's Ratu road and a truck attacked in Latehar. Some more minor sporadic incidents of violence marked the bandh which, police spokesperson S N Pradhan, claimed was largely peaceful. Attempts were made to disrupt railway services in Bokaro and highways at several places in Jharkhand. Pradhan said the MP and MLAs with the supporters were detained from different parts of the state during protests and kept at temporary camps. Nala MLA Ravindra Nath Mahto, Maheshpur MLA Stephen Marandi, Shashi Bhushan Samad MLA of Chakradharpur, Anil Murmu MLA of Littipara, Jagannath Mahto MLA of Dumri, MLA from Mandu Jai Prakash Bhai Patel, Dashrath Gorai MLA of Saraikela, Devendra Mahto MLA of Gomia and Arup Chatterjee MLA of Nirsa were arrested. The bandh was backed by Congress, RJD, JVM-P, Adivasi Moolvasi Janadhikar Manch, Kendriya Sarna Samiti, and Left parties. "The police crackdown was unprecedented and contrary to the democratic values enshrined in the Constitution. Even the peaceful protestors were not spared," JMM spokesperson Supriyo Bhattacharya said. DGP D K Pandey inspected security arrangements in the morning and instructed officers monitoring the deployed personnel. A team from mounted battalion was brought to Ranchi from Hazaribag. The seven horses marching through the city's roads created a sense of fear in the bandh supporters. JMM leader Antu Tirkey said: "As soon as we came out on the street to protest the police detained us. We were not allowed to democratically protest." Majority of 700 persons were detained and confined inside Birsa Munda Football Stadium. Left party leaders, craning their head out of the windows of the bus in which they were ferried shouted that the local resident policy was a betrayal of the tribals faith. The bandh forced closure of marketplaces closed and vehicles were off the highways, said Ranchi SSP Kuldeep Dwivedi. Educational institutions and business centers were closed in Ranchi, Jamshepdur, Dhanbad, Bokaro, Hazaribag, Dumka and other centers. The transport service in towns was absent and buses playing between different districts were stranded at bus depots.
News.Heading: Love is in the armpit at New Yorks Smell Dating
News.text: NEW YORK: Love at first whiff is the idea behind "Smell Dating", a New York matchmaking service that promises to help single people sniff out their perfect match by breathing in the odors from dirty T-shirts. Artist Tega Brain, who teaches at New York's School for Poetic Computation, and Sam Lavigne, an editor and researcher at New York University, created Smell Dating, which they describe as an art project. Each of its first 100 clients received a T-shirt to wear for three days straight without bathing. The clients then mailed the T-shirts back to Brain and Lavigne's "Sweat Shop" at NYU, where they were cut into swatches. Smell Dating then sent batches of 10 mixed swatches back to the clients to sniff this week. A match will be made if one client likes the scent of another and the olfactory attraction is mutual. In other words, if "Client 55" likes "Client 69" and vice versa, put a heart around it, Brain said. The idea is based on the science of pheromones, the chemical signals that creatures from gerbils to giraffes send out to entice mates. Clients, who pay a one-time fee of $25, dive in nose-first, unaware of a potential smell-mate's age, gender or sexual orientation. "Most normal dating services, you rely on profile pictures, assumptions that come from visual information," Brain said. "You either really like the smell of someone or you don't. It's much more innate." On Wednesday, 25-year-old NYU graduate student Jesse Donaldson excitedly opened the package of white swatches in individually numbered plastic bags that had arrived at his apartment in Brooklyn. He said he hoped Smell Dating could help where other popular matchmaking services had failed. "I'm like so many other people in New York City, using Tinder, using OK Cupid," Donaldson said, "and my main issue with these things is you feel like you're shopping for somebody as opposed to making a genuine connection with another human being." Brain said she and Lavigne consulted "a lot of smell researchers" about their art project, which explores whether a person's body odor can trigger Cupid's arrow. "We wanted to see if people would be interested in meeting other people just based on this one bit of information rather than this avalanche of information that you usually get," said Lavigne as he watched volunteers wearing hooded white jumpsuits and blue rubber gloves cut up the worn T-shirts at the Sweat Shop. "Whoa! This one is ready to go!" said a worker, wincing as he sniffed a swatch before putting it into a plastic bag marked #34. In Brooklyn, Donaldson tore into the first plastic bag, removed the swatch and sniffed. "Fresh-done laundry," he said. He opened another and inhaled. "Oh. That is nutty. I'm just going to seal that back up." Then he brought yet another swatch to his nostrils, nodded and said, "Oh." He savored a second whiff and added, "That's my match."
News.Heading: Woman cannot name daughter 'Cyanide': UK court
News.text: LONDON: A mother cannot name her daughter 'Cyanide', a British court has ruled in a landmark case, saying her unusual choice might harm her children. The woman, who also chose the name Preacher for the girl's twin brother, insisted that she had a right to name her own children. But the mother, from Powys, Wales, was thwarted by top judges on Thursday. In the first case of its kind, appeal court judges ruled that it was an "extreme" case and that the mother's "unusual" choices might harm her children. The mother has a chaotic history of mental illness, drug and alcohol abuse and relationships with abusive men, said Lady Justice King. The twins, who are infants, and two of their half-siblings are now living with foster parents, Wales Online reported. When Powys county council social workers learnt of the names the mother had chosen for the twins, they took the case to court in an unprecedented step. In June last year, a judge issued an injunction against the mother, forbidding her from formally registering the twins' unorthodox forenames. Her lawyers appealed, insisting that the refusal to let her name her own children violated her right to respect for family life. Lady Justice King, sitting with Lady Justice Gloster and Lord Justice David Richards, said that naming a little girl after a "notorious poison" was simply unacceptable. Although there was nothing seriously objectionable about the name Preacher, she ruled that both twins' names should be chosen by their older half-siblings. While ruling in the landmark case, the judge said that "even allowing for changes in taste, fashion and developing individual perception," Cyanide was a very odd name to give to a baby girl. The mother said Preacher was a "rather cool name" which sent a "strong spiritual" message and which would "stand my son well for the future". Cyanide, she said, was a "lovely, pretty name" and had positive connotations as the poison which ended the lives of both Hitler and his aide Paul Goebbels. Justice King said the courts would intervene to prevent a parent naming a child "in only the most extreme cases". But she ruled, "This is one of those rare cases where the court should intervene to protect the girl twin from emotional harm that I am satisfied she would suffer if called Cyanide."
News.Heading: Portugal culture minister wants to slap critics
News.text: Critics of Portugal's culture minister are calling on him to be fired for doing something, well, uncultured. After being called "incompetent" and promoting a "work style of chronyism, domineering and rudeness", culture minister Joao Soares reckoned it was time to slap two columnists at an influential newspaper. "I see that I do have to find him (columnist Augusto Seabra), and now also Vasco Pulido Valente, to give them some sound slapping. It will be good for them. And for me," Soares wrote in a Facebook post on Thursday. Sergio Azevedo, deputy bench leader for the main opposition Social Democrats, said Soares' remarks were incompatible with the government job. "There's only one way for him. Out," he wrote on the same social network. The original post garnered over 800 mostly critical comments with many calling for his resignation. The ministry would not comment and Soares, son of former prime minister and president Mario Soares, was not reachable.
News.Heading: Woman posed as man to have sex with teenage girls
News.text: A woman pretended to be a man and used a rubber penis to trick teenage girls into having sex with her. Jennifer Staines was sentenced to 39 months in prison after admitting she set up social media profiles using the name Jason in order to contact the girls, who were aged between 12 and 17 at the time of the offences. In one case, the relationship lasted more than a year. Bristol crown court heard police found a rubber penis and incriminating DNA at Staines' home, and that the 23-year-old would use condoms when sleeping with the girls. She pleaded guilty to sexual assault and two counts of possessing indecent photos of one victim. She also admitted two sexual assaults on a second victim and three sexual assaults on a third. According to Bristol Post, judge Barry Cotter QC told her: "You planned carefully to deceive. You did everything to ensure you had the ability to engage in relationships in which they believed you were a gender you were not. I can't determine whether it was for love, love and sex, or just sex." Investigating officer detective constable Nadine Partridge said: "Jennifer Staines deceived and manipulated her victims into believing she was a young man which is an appalling breach of trust. Her actions were driven by her own selfish desires and although her victims "consented" to sexual activity with her, they were deceived about the true nature of what they were engaging in. The manipulation was so extreme that one of her victims still struggles to believe she was actually in a relationship with a woman, not a man." "The victims and their families have been through a traumatic ordeal and they've found the courage to support the police investigation from the outset. I hope this outcome will help them move on with their lives. I believe there may be more victims out there so I'd encourage anyone who feels they may have been contacted by Jennifer Staines, posing as Jason, to come forward and speak to us. We're here to listen, believe and support you," Partridge added. Last year, a woman was jailed for eight years after pretending to be a man in order to trick her female friend into having sex with her. Gayle Newland put on a deep voice and used a prosthetic penis and a blindfold over almost a dozen sexual encounters during their two-year relationship.
News.Heading: Escaped US inmate found hiding in dishwasher of his girlfriends apartment
News.text: A Texas county jail inmate who escaped custody while receiving treatment in a hospital was found in the dishwasher of his girlfriend's apartment in boxer shorts and wearing handcuffs with the chain severed, a sheriff's department said on Thursday. "He took out the racks and made himself a nice cubby hole," said chief deputy Glenn Blank of the Jasper county sheriff's office in East Texas. The inmate, Wesley Evans, 20, was captured on Wednesday morning and was taken back into custody after an escape that lasted about 24 hours. He is expected to face charges for the escape attempt. Evans has been in jail since March 8 on charges of aggravated robbery, auto theft and arson. He was taken to the hospital for treatment of a swollen hand.
News.Heading: US man faces jail for refusing to take down Donald Trump flag
News.text: NEW YORK: Republican presidential hopeful Donald Trump appears to have a passionate supporter in Joseph Hornick, a New Jersey man who faces a $2,000 fine or 90 days in jail for flying a flag emblazoned with the billionaire candidate's name over his home. Local officials said the flag violates an ordinance prohibiting the display of political signs more than 30 days ahead of an election and issued him a summons. New Jersey's primary is on June 7. For weeks, Hornick has displayed the blue flag with Trump's "Make America Great Again!" campaign slogan on a pole outside his two-story West Long Branch house, at a busy intersection near Monmouth University, in a show of his support for Trump. Trump has been campaigning this week in neighboring New York in an effort to snag the Republican presidential nomination. Despite being issued a summons on March 25 for the violation, Hornick apparently intends to keep it up. "The fine can be in the Millions of dollars! That flag will never come down!" he wrote in a defiant Facebook post. Hornick did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Lori Cole, West Long Branch's clerk, said on Friday that Hornick, 54, could also face 90 days in jail as a maximum penalty if a judge determines he is in violation of the law. "It just came up recently," she said of the controversy. Brian Hegarty, a former Democratic Party councilman, complained to authorities about Hornick's flag, according to a March 25 police report. Hegarty told police that he had complained several times about the flag to a code enforcement official, but no action was taken. Sergeant James Gomez in the report said Hornick initially agreed to take down the flag before speaking with his attorney. "He advised on the advice of an attorney he would not be removing the flag and would fight any summons issued to him," Gomez wrote. Hornick is scheduled to appear in court on April 20.
News.Heading: Ohio home of serial killer for rent during Republican convention
News.text: CLEVELAND: The Ohio childhood home of serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer, available for rent in time for the Republican National Convention this summer, could have been had for $8,000 a month until Friday afternoon, when the price went up and references to the infamous criminal came down. The home where Dahmer grew up and in 1978 committed his first murder is in Bath, Ohio, 26 miles south of Cleveland, where the convention is scheduled to be held in July. The listing on a real-estate company website initially included a reference to Dahmer but on Friday that was removed and the price had been increased to $10,000 a month. Dahmer was convicted in 1992 in the murder and dismemberment of 17 boys and men, some of whom he ate, over a period of 14 years. He was beaten to death in 1994 by another prison inmate while serving 15 life terms in Wisconsin, where most of the murders took place after he moved there. The listing by Howard Hanna, the official real estate broker for the convention, had been up since February and initially included the fact that the three-bedroom, two-bathroom, 2,170-square-foot home was once occupied by Dahmer. It had described the house as a "mid-century modern home with a true park-like setting. Smoking and animals okay. This is Jeffrey Dahmer's childhood home. Close to Cuyahoga Valley National Park, Montrose shopping. Easy access to I-77 highway." By Friday afternoon, the Dahmer sentence had been removed. Julia Domenick, the listing agent at Hanna, could not be reached for comment. In 1978, at age 18, Dahmer killed a teenaged hitchhiker, then dismembered and buried the body in a shallow grave behind the Bath house. Homeowner Chris Butler, a member of the Akron-based punk band The Waitresses, bought the house in 2005 for $295,000 after its history was disclosed. He could not be reached for comment.
News.Heading: Drone hunt for Loch Ness Monster finds its film double
News.text: A high-tech marine drone scouring the depths of Scotland's Loch Ness for one of nature's most elusive beasts has found a "monster" but not the one it was looking for. Rather than the fabled Loch Ness Monster itself, the probe has discovered a 30-foot (9 metre) replica used in the 1970 film "The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes", which sank nearly 50 years ago after its buoyant humps were removed. Undeterred, the enthusiastic monster-hunters steering the drone are continuing their two-week search for any evidence that might prove the existence of "Nessie". The survey by Norwegian company Kongsberg Maritime has been the most detailed to date of the Loch's icy depths. The Munin drone is capable of mapping vast areas down to 1,500 feet and is often used to locate downed aircraft. "The vehicle allows sonars to scan just a few metres from the loch floor, giving resolution several orders of magnitude greater than anything before," said Kongsberg Maritime engineer Craig Wallace. Along with the movie replica, it has also found a 27-foot shipwreck as it maps the Loch floor. Far from being disappointed by the findings, Steve Feltham who has been hunting Nessie for 25 years, says the maps will help him in his quest. "I think the findings are fantastic," he said. "We now have a more detailed map of the rock bottom than ever before, which will show us the location of every lump and bump. "We can send back cameras to look at anything of interest which could turn out to be the carcass of the animal," he added. "It's shown there's a hell of a lot more to investigate." The first written record of a monster relates to the Irish monk St Columba, who is said to have banished a "water beast" to the depths of the River Ness in the 6th century. The most famous picture of Nessie, known as the "surgeon's photo", was taken in 1934 and showed a head on a long neck emerging from the water. It was revealed 60 years later to have been a hoax that used a sea monster model attached to a toy submarine. Countless unsuccessful attempts to track down the monster have been made in the years since, notably in 2003 when the BBC funded an extensive scientific search that used 600 sonar beams and satellite tracking to sweep the full length of the loch. It concluded there was probably nothing there.
News.Heading: Flight attendant leaves packed plane using emergency slide
News.text: AUSTIN (Texas): A flight attendant deployed an emergency evacuation slide on an airplane after it arrived in Houston and used it to exit a plane packed with passengers, an airline official said. "It is our understanding that she deployed it intentionally," said United Airlines spokesman Charlie Hobart, adding airline officials have been speaking with the flight attendant to see why she deployed the slide in the incident that took place on Monday. In a video shown on Houston TV station KPRC, the flight attendant tosses her bag out of a door behind the cockpit and slides down the slide. She grabs the bag and walks away from the plane, which was at full stop. A photo of the airplane on the station's website shows it at the gate, with the slide deployed on the side opposite of the gate. The flight, with 159 passengers and six crew members aboard, was from Sacramento to Houston's George Bush Intercontinental Airport. The airplane, a Boeing 737-900, was briefly taken out of service for maintenance and then was returned to its scheduled use. The flight attendant, who was not identified by the airline, has been removed from flying duties. All the others aboard exited the plane without incident or injury.
News.Heading: Thai woman faces sedition trial for posing with plastic bowl
News.text: BANGKOK: A Thai woman has been charged with sedition, police said on Tuesday, after photos were spread of her holding a red bowl allegedly bearing a message from an ex-premier who lies at the heart of the kingdom's bitter politics. The images showed Theerawan Charoensuk, 54, holding a hand-sized bowl with a goodwill note apparently signed by former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, whose powerful political dynasty is locked in a decadelong struggle with the kingdom's military-backed royalist elite. She faces up to seven years in jail if convicted. Her arrest comes as the ruling junta, who toppled a government led by Thaksin's sister in 2014, hardens its clampdown on political expression ahead of a referendum on a controversial charter it has penned. The small bowl is used to pour water during Buddhist ceremonies and was distributed at a temple fair in northern Chiang Mai, the Shinawatra's hometown. It was painted red a colour with strong associations to the family's supporters, who are known as the "Red Shirts". Local media reported it was signed by Thaksin along with a slogan that read: "The situation may be hot, but brothers and sisters may gain coolness from the water inside this bucket". Police declined to comment on the details of the bowl, saying only that they believed it was handed out by a "certain political party". "She was charged with section 116 inciting chaos in the country," said Nateephat Akarapongthiti from Chiang Mai's Mae Ping police station. The junta has outlawed all political activities and protests since the coup, in a vow to bridge the kingdom's vast divides. But critics say the generals are more focused on rooting out the influence of the Shinawatras, who have dominated electoral politics for the past 10 years and are seen as a threat to the elite's status quo. Junta chief Prayut Chan-O-Cha told reporters Tuesday he found the charge was "suitable" because "it might be a national security threat". "It was [a show of] support for people who have violated laws and run away from criminal charge," he said, a reference to Thaksin, who lives in self-imposed exile to avoid a corruption conviction. Police said Theerawan, a Chiang Mai resident, was released from custody today and will now face trial in a military court. "She said she held up the bowl, but she didn't think that was wrong," Nateephat told AFP. Rights groups say the junta has increasingly leaned on the country's tough sedition law to silence critics.
News.Heading: Size matters at Japans phallus festival
News.text: KAWASAKI: Japanese revellers carried giant phalluses through the streets of Kawasaki on Sunday to worship the humble penis and fertility in one of the world's most unusual festivals. Size matters at the Shinto Kanamara Matsuri, where groups of locals parade three heavy phalluses around the city the biggest as tall as a full-grown man.
